messages.text:
I need to develop a test framework for some control software that will:
1. use reactive programming
2. use a predetermined schedule
3. be deterministic and repeatable for a given schedule
4. allow for data to be intercepted so that they can be "corrupted" according to the test schedule: i.e. some values zeroed out or turned missing, noise added, delayed
I think I can do all of these things with Rocket.jl. Can anyone see any issues or have any experience with this kind of thing?

elements.text: I need to develop a test framework for some control software that will:
use reactive programming
use a predetermined schedule
be deterministic and repeatable for a given schedule
allow for data to be intercepted so that they can be "corrupted" according to the test schedule: i.e. some values zeroed out or turned missing, noise added, delayed
I think I can do all of these things with Rocket.jl. Can anyone see any issues or have any experience with this kind of thing?

messages.text: I have been watching Robotics Science and Systems 2020 and 2019 recordings. I noticed that 2019 had a lot more talks mentioning Julia. Thanks to everyone who presented there.

Anyone aware of the state of the Caesar.jl packages. I have tried running some examples in the documentation unsuccessfully, it seems there's often something broken with the RoME/RoMEPlotting packages.
If RoMEPlotting is broken, are there alternatives I could use?

It seems like its kinda dead...

messages.text:
> indeed ... I have never seen any messages here since I joined, and the last update to the website was on 2018
I have exchanged several messages here over the past year or two. It's just that Slack eats the messages very fast and we can't see them. E.g., right now we can't see messages before the 8th Jan 2021─that's only 10 days ago!

messages.text: As <@U01AJUF2GEP> says, the robotics community is very small compared to the other communities using Julia. Perhaps we should all head over to Zulip? There's already a <https://julialang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/250831-robotics|Robotics stream> there, the messages will not vanish, and we can organise things with topics.

messages.text: I for one am really excited every time I see the <#CGJQSSPRP|robotics> highlighted here in Slack. It's a bit unfortunate that more discussions are not taking place.

messages.text:
> Any idea if the JuliaRobotics packages are still maintained or not?
I have been mostly using three packages from the robotics community: <https://github.com/rdeits/MeshCat.jl|MeshCat.jl>, <https://github.com/JuliaRobotics/MeshCatMechanisms.jl|MeshCatMechanisms.jl>, and <https://github.com/JuliaRobotics/RigidBodyDynamics.jl|RigidBodyDynamics.jl>. The authors of those packages have left academia and are now working, so the development has slowed down compared to when they were in academia. However, MeshCat.jl is still very well maintained (latest commit was ~3 weeks ago. RigidBodyDynamics.jl has not had a commit to master for more than 3 months, but honestly I have been quite happy with its current state.

elements.text: Any idea if the JuliaRobotics packages are still maintained or not?
I have been mostly using three packages from the robotics community:
MeshCat.jl
MeshCatMechanisms.jl
, and
RigidBodyDynamics.jl

. The authors of those packages have left academia and are now working, so the development has slowed down compared to when they were in academia. However, MeshCat.jl is still very well maintained (latest commit was ~3 weeks ago. RigidBodyDynamics.jl has not had a commit to master for more than 3 months, but honestly I have been quite happy with its current state.

messages.text: I am not really sure how it works to get repositories under the JuliaRobotics organisation. I have two repositories that probably would be better located there for visibility and "discoverability": <https://github.com/ferrolho/TORA.jl|TORA.jl> and <https://github.com/ferrolho/ModernRoboticsBook.jl|ModernRoboticsBook.jl>.

messages.text:
How interested would <#CGJQSSPRP> be in me completing the JuMP wrapper for a third NLP solver with a free academic license and multi month free evaluation period for commercial user?
I can't find the movitivation to write some ugly piece of code to make the next step but that people might be interested in it could help. Here are the cutest results of the solver on unspecified hardware <https://worhp.de/content/cutest#cutest_ip>
I've been happy with Ipopt and Knitro, though Knitro is not free. Are those not good enough for what you need?

elements.text: I've been happy with Ipopt and Knitro, though Knitro is not free. Are those not good enough for what you need?
